semantic_identifier: 1707555 - Timberline Metro Transit - sales_pitch - Discussion with Rhea Narang

hierarchy.meeting_title: 1707555 - Timberline Metro Transit - sales_pitch - Discussion with Rhea Narang

sections.text: James Choi: Hi Rhea—James Choi here. Thanks for taking a few minutes. I’ll keep it tight. I’m calling because we built Customer_Analyzer to help teams like yours get really clear on which customer segments are actually your best fit—and then use that to prioritize roadmap and messaging. Does that map to anything you’re working on at Timberline Metro Transit right now?
Rhea Narang: Hi James. We’re in the middle of a few initiatives, but I’m not sure we’re looking for new tooling at the moment. What exactly does it do?

James Choi: Totally fair. In one sentence: we ingest the customer signals you already have—CRM fields, onboarding surveys, product usage events, support tickets, even interview notes—and we turn it into a fit score from 0 to 100 at the account and segment level, plus a breakdown of why. The practical outcome is you can see, for example, “Segment A renews and expands, Segment B churns,” and which drivers are behind that.
Rhea Narang: Okay. We already have reporting in our CRM and some dashboards. How is this different from analytics we can build internally?

James Choi: Great question. The difference is it’s not just reporting—it’s fit estimation that’s oriented around outcomes. You define fit drivers that matter to you—industry or size, problem severity, willingness to pay, time-to-value, adoption patterns, support burden, churn risk signals—then we score accounts and segments and show a driver-level explanation. So rather than “usage is down,” it becomes “this segment’s support burden and time-to-value make them low-fit, and that’s correlated with churn.” It’s meant to help teams align on an ICP and make sharper calls.
Rhea Narang: I get the concept. But we’re a transit organization—our “customers” are a mix of internal stakeholders, riders, partners. I’m not sure your model applies cleanly.

James Choi: That makes sense, and it’s a common question. When I say “customer,” it can be any account or segment you’re trying to serve consistently—partners, agencies, departments, even rider cohorts if you have the signals. The use case I see most for teams like yours is product planning: identifying the high-fit segments with unmet needs, so roadmap bets are driven by the groups most likely to adopt and stick.
Rhea Narang: We do product planning, but our constraints are often policy and budget cycles. I’m not sure a fit score changes that.

James Choi: Understood. It may not change constraints, but it can help you decide where you invest within them. For instance, if you’re choosing between two initiatives, the fit estimation can show which segment will reach value faster and require less support burden—so you’re not unintentionally prioritizing segments that look loud but are historically low adoption or high churn risk.
Rhea Narang: We don’t really think in terms of churn, and support burden is hard to quantify for us. Also, we have limited engineering bandwidth to integrate anything new.

James Choi: On integration, we try to keep it light. A lot of teams start with just CRM exports plus onboarding or survey data, and optionally support tickets. You can add product usage events later if that’s available. On support burden, we can proxy it from ticket volumes, categories, time-to-resolution, or even qualitative tags from notes—doesn’t have to be perfect to be directional.
Rhea Narang: But we’d still have to clean and map all that data. And I’m not convinced we’d trust an automated scoring model enough to base decisions on it.

James Choi: That’s fair. The way we address trust is with the driver breakdown. It’s not a black box “this is your ICP.” It shows why a segment scored high or low—like time-to-value, adoption, ticket volume—so your team can sanity-check it. If you disagree with a driver, you can adjust weights or definitions and see the impact.
Rhea Narang: That sounds like a lot of tuning. Honestly, we have a pretty good sense of who our priority segments are already, even if it’s not quantified.

James Choi: If you already have strong intuition, Customer_Analyzer can help validate it quickly—and sometimes reveal edge cases. For example, a segment you assume is high value might convert, but require outsized support and never expands; while another segment quietly renews with low effort. The tool helps make those trade-offs explicit for planning.

Rhea Narang: I’m not saying it’s useless. I just don’t have a current project where I could justify evaluating and implementing this. We’re also in a procurement freeze for new SaaS for at least this quarter.

James Choi: Got it—thanks for being direct. In that case, would it be helpful if I sent a one-pager focused on the product planning use case—how teams use fit estimation to identify high-fit customers with unmet needs—so you have it if priorities shift?
Rhea Narang: You can send it, but I can’t promise I’ll get to it soon.
James Choi: Totally understood. Before I do—quick check: who usually owns ICP or segment prioritization on your side? Is that product, strategy, or someone in analytics?
Rhea Narang: It’s shared. Product has input, but strategy and operations are heavily involved. Analytics supports when we can.

James Choi: That helps. If you think it’s appropriate, I can address the one-pager to that broader group and keep it non-salesy—more “here’s a framework and what data signals it uses.” And if later you want to explore, we can do a short working session rather than a full pitch.
Rhea Narang: Maybe. But again, we can’t buy tools right now, and I’m hesitant to pull more people into something we can’t act on.

James Choi: Completely fair. Then I’ll keep it simple: I’ll send a concise overview and a sample fit driver list—things like time-to-value proxies, adoption indicators, and support load—so you can see whether it matches your environment. No follow-up cadence unless you reply.
Rhea Narang: Okay, that’s fine. Send it over.
James Choi: Will do. Last quick question so I tailor it: do you have any consistent sources like ticketing, surveys, or a CRM-like system for partner engagements, or is it mostly ad hoc?
Rhea Narang: We have a ticketing system and some survey data, but it’s fragmented. And we’re not looking to connect more systems right now.

James Choi: Understood. I’ll frame it as “start with what you have,” and I’ll include an example of using just tickets and survey signals to estimate fit at a segment level. Thanks again for the time, Rhea.
Rhea Narang: Thanks, James. I’ll look when I can.
James Choi: Appreciate it. I’ll send that shortly. Have a good rest of your day.
Rhea Narang: You too.
